div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, APRIL 17, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oreintal S.N. Comapny.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
For the convenience of families and other berths can be definitely engaged at once.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Scakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor,(for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Beautiful weather prevailed yesterday and favoured holida-makers. There was a moderate and bracing wind, which tempered the heat of the sun. This morning the sky is overcast and the light N.E. breeze is blowing. The barometer is steady.

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: CARVER- On 15th April, at the Anglo-American Hospital, Ghezirah, Cairo the wife of Herbert S. Carver, of a son.

div.head: Turkey and Egypt
Tuesday, April 17, 1906
div.p: Oar oontemporary “A1 Lew*” states that Ghari Mukhtar Pacha, on behalf of the Porte, demands what praotioally amounts to the oeision of the Sinai Feninsala and permisrion to oonitrnot a railway from Akaba to Suez. That such amazing demands should have been made argues a remarkable lack of humour on the part of the Ottoman Government, whoee next demand, we suppose, will be for the oession of Zsgasig, Ismailia, and -Bel be is. Doee the Porte seriously believe that Egypt can consent to the occupation of the Sinai— the natnral buffer between Turkey and the dominions of the Khedive—by Ottoman forces, or to the oo ns traction of a railway which can only le of strategical value to a would-be invader t It may be nrged that oar Nationalist contemporary has been misinformed. It is true that “Al Lewa” has always shown a remarkable dexterity in misinterpreting motives - espe- cially those cf the higher British offioials who have done yeoman’s servioe to the Khedivial Government—bat the olose relations that exist between Mnstapha Pacha Kamel and the Ottoman High Commissioner it more than probable that his description of the Porte’s demands is absolutely correot As to the attitude of the Egyptian Press we are glad to reoognise that the Bnropean organs of Alexandria and Cairo have long realised that the prinoiplea for whioh the Rgyptian Government is contending in de- manding the evaoaation of Tahah are just and patriotic. Egypt cannot afford to see the gap of desert that separates her from her powerful neighboor bridged by Otto- man military poets end strategical railways. Her isolation has been one of the factors of her prosperity. True, she owes mnoh to good government, to the industry ot her peasantry, and to the great public works that have increased her resources and defy nature in her most niggard yean; bat had she been compelled to arm against powerful neighbours, to guard all her frontiers against the of invasion, to wateh with anxiety any distur- bance in the political equilibrium of the Levant, her progress, however exoellentber goverument, mast have been terribly delayed. Of our vernacular contemporaries, some realise the danger, bat there ere others that hail it- as a blessing. The Nationalist appreciations ot the situation are an interesting study. They demand constitutions and chambers of deputies —enlarging at the asms time on the rights in Egypt of the Saltan to whom such things era anathema. They oomplain that British in- flnenoe in Egypt is exercised with the sole objeot cf keeping its people in snbjeetion, and openly^invite the interference of a race that regards the Egyptian with ill-oonooaled con- tempt. We might panne the contradictions that are involved in the policy whioh they advocate still farther. Euoagh that the Government remains and will remain unmoved by their criticisms, that it will continoe its policy of opposition to Turkish olaims on the Eastern frontier, and that its opposition will have the support of Britain and the British Empire. Whether the claims of the Ottoman Govern- ment are likely to be supported by *Ly Bnropean Power is an interesting question on which we will not enlarge, oon ten ting ourselvaa with asking some of out Nationalist confreres iriwther they know the story of the oat (doubtless an Angora), the monkey, and the ohestnnts.

div.head: ROSE'S LIME JUICE
div.p: DELICIOUS, Wholesome & Refreshing.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Ras el-Tin School. The gymnastic display of the pupils of Ras el Tin Government school will take place next Thursday afternoon, at 3 o’clock.
Al Hayat. The Al Hayat Hotel Company of Helonan has purchased the Giovanni Estate on the Nile bank opposite Bedrasheen in order to construct a first class restaurant and resort there.

The Union Jack. A correspondent writes: On Easter Sunday, and for several Sundays past, the Union Jack has been hoisted upside down on Fort Kom- el-Dick. Are we to infer that the British Army is just at present in a worse way than

Home International. The Home International was opened on the 2nd inst. at No. 7, Rue Gessi Pacha. Alexandria. Girls of all nationalities and creeds are received at the price of fra. 1.50 a day for board and lodging, or fn. 2 for a separate room. The matron will be pleased to show the Home to any ladies who may wish to visit it

New House of Rest. Residents in Alexandria and Ramleh are invited to attend the laying of the foundation stone of “Fairhaven,” a house of rest for missionaries by the sea, by the Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D. D, Archdeacon of Egypt, on Wednesday, 18th inst., at 4.30 p m The Bite is three minutes walk from Palais Station, on the brow of the hill southwards.

This company’s estate at Mandi is being rapidly absorbed by investors in land. Of the total estate of 450 feddans, about 950 lots of a thousand square metres each have been already sold at prices ranging from P.T. 35 to P.T. 100 per metre. The entire estate was purchased only eighteen months ago for less than £100,000.

An Unpleasant Incident. We hear that an official belonging to the Ministry of Public Instruction has found himself obliged to choose one of two alternatives, i.e, resigning his official position or standing his trial before the British Consular Court, on account of a dispute with a policeman on Hast el Nil Bridge, Cairo, in which a technical assault appears to have been committed. It is felt in some quarters that the punishment is rather too severe for the crime, while, on the other side, it is staled that the said official had already been Involved in similar incidents. The case is exciting considerable interest, especially among officials.

Man Cut in Two. A fatal accident occurred at Round Point yesterday evening. As is usual on Shorn el Nessim, the tramcars were largely patronised and considerable overcrowding took place. It is only surprising that we have not more accidents to chronicle. About 7 p.m., an Armenian of 30 years, in the scramble to secure seats, attempted to pass from one oar to another and fell between the two, the wheels of one passing over his body and cutting it in halves. It seems incredible, but we have it on good authority, that the mutilated remains of the unfortunate man were left lying on the spot for-close on two hours before being removed by the police.
Spend your Holidays at Mena, The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. ( Advt.]

The funeral of the late M. Felix Snares took place yesterday, deceased’s body being conveyed to Alexandria for interment in the family vault.'’ The ceremony commenced at 9.40 a.m. at deceased’s Cairo residence, opposite the offices of the Credit Foncier, whence the body was conveyed to the station, followed by a large and distinguished gathering of mourners, including H.H. Prince Hussein, the Ministers, Lord Cromer, the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, etc. There were numerous wreaths, among others one from the Credit Foncier and most of the remainder from Italian benevolent institutions which had benefited by deceased’s benefactions daring his lifetime.

The special train conveying the mortal remains of the deceased left Cairo at 11.30, a large number of the mourners accompanying the body. Previous to the train departing several speeches were delivered at the ata1 ion by among others M. P. Oziol, M. Brandani, etc.

There was rather an unpleasant incident at the station, a number of the power Jews who had been pressing forward to touch the coffin of their dead benefactor being pushed back by the police. A scuffle followed which under the circumstances could only be characterised as unseemly. Three policemen were knocked down and a couple of arrests were made.

The train arrived at Alexandria at 2.40 p.m. and an enormous crowd was waiting to follow the hearse to the cemetery, including everybody of note in the city. The Grand Rabbi conducted the service at the Jewish cemetery and the late M Suares was laid to rest with the other members of the family who have pre-deceased him in the family vault ^
The special train conveying the Cairo mourners back to the Capital left at 5.30 p.m.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: SPEECH BY PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT
EXPOSES SOCIALISTIC DOCTRINES. (Gazette’s Special Service.) London, Monday

President Roosevelt on Saturday made an important address on social political problems, attacking American Press methods, with special reference to the attacks on Senators, referring to such as mudrake.

He suggested the imposition of special taxation on millionaires, both corporate and individual, discriminating in the sharpest way between fortunes well won and ill won. No amount of charity in the spending of such fortunes could compensate, he said, for the misconduct occasioned in the making of them. The taxation would be aimed merely at inheritances or the transmission in entirety of fortunes swollen beyond healthy limits.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive arrived at Montazah Palace on Saturday evening from Cairo, and will stay for a week in Alexandria. On Saturday next his Highness will open the Flower Show at San Stefano and in the evening of the same day will return to Cairo.

His Highness who is coming to Alexandria for the summer from Cairo on the 30th inst., will leave for Europe about the middle of June. The date of his Highness’s departure is not fixed as he will probably wait for the return of the Mahroussa from the Clyde before leaving Egypt.
On returning to Egypt from Europe his Highness will remain at Alexandria until after the feast of Beyram.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION
div.p: Nothing is known as to the farther progress of the negotiations between Egypt and Turkey on the frontier question. News from the "front” remains unimportant. The "Diana,” whose officers and crew are beginning to find the gulf of Akaba a somewhat monotonous station, remains oft Akaba and part of the Turkish garrison has shifted its camp to a bill near the village. Sunday picnics— at which hundreds of excellent oysters, which are to be found on the Egyptian shore of the gulf, are consumed— and golf employ the energies of the British naval officers.

The discovery of oysters is of interest in that it proves that the gulf of Akaba produces something, and should farther encourage the Ministry of Foreign Affairs—if encouragement were needed—to insist on the Egyptian ownership of its western shore. Why abandon rich beds—the very existence of which will doubtless tempt some of our financiers to promote "The Ezion-Gebir Dredging Company” or the "Whelks and Oysters Trust”—to ■•cultivated persons from Asia Minor who have never eaten an oyster in their lives 1

Our Cairo Correspondent telephones : — It is understood that the Egyptian Govern ment his absolutely refused to entertain the proposals of the Sublime Ottoman Porte and that fresh proposals on the part of the Porte are now awaited.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS
div.p: The "London Gazette” announces that the King has been pleased to grant to the following officers his Majesty's Royal licence and authority to accept and wear decorations which have been conferred upon them by the Khedive of Egypt, authorized by the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness :—Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, Third Class. —Major C. K G. Blunt, A.S.C. (retired). Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, Third Class. Major B. A. Dickinson, Royal Dbblin Fusiliers. Imperial Ottoman Order of the Oamanieh, Fourth Class.—Major J. H. Rivers, R A.M.C.; Captain H. D. W. Lloyd, the Cameronians ; Captain H. H. S. Morant, Durham L. I. ; and Captain H. G. F. Stallard, R.A.M.C.

div.head: SAN STEFANO HOTEL CASINO
div.p: The San Stefano Hotel Casino will open its doors for the summer season at the beginning of next month. Immense improvements have been made during the winter months in the building, which has been greatly enlarged and improved. Altogether forty new bedrooms have been added, all facing due north. Sixteen separate suites, comprising bedroom, sitting-room, bath-room, etc., have been made, each being quite private. A large entrance hall has been made and a new dining-room capable of accommodating two hundred guests has been built. The furniture has been renewed. Stables for ten horses and a motor garage are also at the present time being made.

In future the hotel will be open both winter and summer. Mr. Landaner will, as usual, have the management, which has been in his experienced bands for the last six seasons. Mr. Fritz Fischer will again be the maitre d hotel.
The sea-bathing establishment is to be entirely renewed. The restaurant will be run exactly in the same style as that of the Savoy Hotel at Cairo.

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES
PREPARATIONS FOR KING EDWARD'S RECEPTION.
div.p: (From ode Special Correspondent). Athens, April 11.
Great preparations are being made here for the reception of King Edward, Queen Alexandra, and the Prince and Princess of Wales, who are expected to arrive at Athens in the early part of Easter week.

The cruisers Spetzia and Pears, the gunboat Miaoulis, and two torpedo-boats have been ordered to be off Ydra island on Thursday to await the arrival to the Royal Yacht Victoria and Albert and escort her to Phaleron Bay, where the cruiser Ydra will be in attendance to salute the Royal yacht on her arrival there. - The Victoria and Albert will be escorted by King George's yacht Amphitrite, H. M. S. Renown, with the Prince and Princess of Wales on board, and Admiral Lord Chas. Beresford’s squadron, composed of H.M.S. Bulwark, Prince of Wales, Irresistible, Implacable, Leviathan, Lancaster, Vulcan, Surprise, Barham, and five torpedo-destroyers, besides H.M.S. Terrible, which is escorting the Renown.
Admiral Zotos and Capt. Zohias, of the Greek Navy, and Col. Soutsos, of the Cavalry, have been appointed to be in attendance upon King Edward daring his stay in Athens.

The approaching Olympic Games are exciting an extraordinary amount of interest amongst the Greek element in Cairo, and two or three youths, whose expenses are to be paid by a wealthy resident of the Capital, intend proceeding to Athens to compete.

Amongst the prominent members of the Hellenic community of Cairo who are proceeding to the Piraeus by the Khedivial mail steamer of next Wednesday are Rustowitz Bey, president of the community, Mr. Nestor Gianaclis, Nungovich Bey, Ranghabe Bey, Mr. Gennarapoulo, Mr. P. Bellenis, and Mr. Chelmis.

div.head: IMPORTANT FORTHCOMING FLOTAION.
A NEW LOAN BANK.
div.p: Among the many new companies shortly to be floated in Egypt is one of great importance in view of the amount of its capital and the great support which it is to receive from many leading local capitalists. It is to be a loan bank and its operations will chiefly consist in I lending money on first-class real property I securities. The promotion is to be entrusted to a prominent financial establishment at Alexandria. The capital of this new concern, which will be half a million, has already been subscribed. There will probably be a public issue.

div.head: CAIRO HELOUNAN RAILWAY
div.p: A number of first-class corridor carriages on bogies of Belgian make have been put on the Helouan Railway. The carriages are fitted op with the latest modern conveniences, such as ventilating fans, electric light, etc. They are superior to any carriages on any other railway in the country. They ran with great ease and have given general satisfaction. Each carriage cost nearly £2,500. A number of Seooud-ola88 corridor oars in a similar style have also been ordered.

The line from the Sayeda Zenab station to Tourah is now being doubled and an automatic brake will be fitted to all trains in the course of the summer. It is understood that a more frequent service will be intro duced in the coming winter season.
The new station at Maadi is about to be constructed for the new suburban traffic which will spring into existence as soon as Maadi becomes a residential suburb of Cairo.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: The secretary informs us that the railhead on the line under construction is now at kilometre 19 J. Ten of the new wagons have been wheeled, and the new locomotives are being delivered at the base. The buildings at the base are nearing completion. In the oases, in consequence of the increased supply of water obtained by deepening No. 6 bore, additional land has been prepared in the vicinity and partly sown. 677 date palms are now at this bore. Some of the cereal crops are ripening and will soon be ready for harvest.

div.head: NILE VALLEY RECONSTRUCTION
div.p: With regard to reconstruction of the Nile Valley Company, it is stated that more than 194,000 shares in the new company have been claimed by shareholders in the old company, resident in England, and the first batch of allotment letters has been posted.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Sunday’s bulletin reports two deaths and two fatal cases at Deshna and a fatal case at Wasta, the victim being a person who came from Mansourah.
Yesterday there were 7 cases at Deshna, two of which proved fatal, and two deaths in hospital there.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
SHEM EL NESSIM SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Lovely weather favoured the Shem-el-Nessim Meeting of the A. S. C. yesterday, and there was in consequence a very large attendance of the public, the enclosure presenting a bright and animated appearance and the afternoon proving a most enjoyable one. The greatest interest was taken in the racing, and the Pari Mutuel was largely patronised, the odds in many oases being very good, especially in the Regimental Cup, when the fortunate backers of Grey Dawn received P.T. 750 for their dollar. The coarse was in splendid condition and the racing was on the whole good. The most exciting finish of the day was provided by the Regimental Cap, when Grey Dawn and Soliman came in neck and neck. An accident occurred in that race, when 8t. Patrick’s rider was thrown but, fortunately, received no serious injuries. The last race, the April Stakes, was a walk-over for Roi de l’Air. The races were witnessed by large crowds of holiday-making spectators who occupied every point of vantage along the course. The band of the 1st Royal Dablin Fusiliers, under Bandmaster Fawcett, (discoursed a choice selection of music which added greatly to the pleasure of the afternoon. The following are particulars of the racing^—

Novices Race of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never ran in a race of My description, Amateur raoces and Gymkhanas excepted. Horses 10.7, Galloways 10 3, and ponies 10.0. Distance 5 furlongs.

Saleh Bey Yaghen’s c.a.h. Tamerlan II., 1Q.7. Whiteside. , 1 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s oh.a.h. Atoohe, 10.3 Kamel Effendi. ; 2 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.p. Atbara, 10.0. Parsons. 3 Mr. E. Karam’s g.a.h. Douglas, 10.7. Miohaeli- des Jun. 0 Khalil Pacha Kbayat’s b.a.h. Kassban II., 10.3. Thompson. 0 Baron J.E. de Menasce’s br.a.p. Val d’Or, 10.0. Matthews. 0 Prinoe Omar Pacha Tonssonn’s g.a.h. Owner. / 0

Owing to its having taken place behind the pigeon-shooting enclosure, the start was not seen. Tamerlan II. was the first to emerge from the cutting with Atbara and Val d’Or a couple of lengths behind. This order was maintained until nearing the grand-stand, when Ateche crept np and passed the two latter horses, taking second place from Tamerlan II. by two lengths. A length separated second and third. Val d’Or was fourth. Time : 1.9.
Totalisator paid P.T. 60 on winner and P.T. 27, 104, and 217 for places.

Maiden Pony Plate of P.T, 2,500, viz: P.T. 2,000 to winner and P T. 500 to 9nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies. Weight for ace and inches. Distance 1 mile. H E. Hussein Paoha Sioofi’s g.a.p. Abon Nadara, 10.7. Mr. Paravioini. 1 Baron J.E. de Menasoe’s g.a.p. Radium, 10.7. Matthews. f 2 H.H. Prince Omar Pacha Toussonn’s b.a.h. Beylan, 10.3. Ibrahim Bastawissi, 3 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s b.a.p. Soudan, 10.3. Parsons. 0 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p.Balkeley,lC.7 White- side. 0 Mr. B. Karam’s b. a. p. Chater, 10.7. Miohae- lides Jun. 0
H.E. Khalil Pasha Khayat’s oh.a.p. Doughan, 10 3. Burnham. 0 Mr. A. J. Suraook’s g.a.h. Rny-Blas, 10.7. Stillwell. 0

The lot went off in a bunch, Abon Nadara and Radium leading. The pair showed the way into the straight, with the rest of the field all riding. An excellent race down the straight ended in Abon Nadara scouring first place from Radium by nearly two lengths, Beylan being a length behind, third, Time: 1.54.
Totalisator paid P.T. 60 on winner and P.T. 33, 34, and 91 for places.
Trial Plate of P.T. 2,500, v’z: P.T. 9,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age. Distance 6 furlongs.

Ishack Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din’s cb.a.p. Lahek, 10.7. Megahed. 1 Ishack Bey Hussein’s ch.a.h. El Tahawi, 10.7. Stillwell. 9 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.s.h. Chendi, 10.7. Kamel Effendi. 3 Prinoe Omar Pasha Tousaoun’s g.a.h. Shne'inan, 10 6. Ibrahim Bastawiss. 0 Mr. E. Karam’s g,a.h. Bayard, 10.9. Elia. 0 „ „ „ Voltigenr. 10.6. Mi- ohaelides Jan. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.h. Derwiche, 10.7 Edward. _ 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.h. Dynamite, 10.6. ParsonB. * % 0 Mr. A J. Sursock’s b.a.h. Prinoe Soleil, 10.7. Mr. Paravioini. 0 Damn J. E de Menasoe’s oh.a.h. Ajax, 10.7. Matthews. 0

El Tahawi was the first to get away from a good start and led into the cutting, but was soon overtaken by Lahek, who took np the lead and maintained it all down the straight, winning from El Tahawi by a couple of lengths. Chendi lost second place by a bare_ half-length, the rest dose np. A good race. Time: 1.29£.
Totalizator paid P.T. 106 on winner and P.T. 35, 28, and 45 for places.

Regimental Cup.— Handicap for all horses the property of officers of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers. Distance round the Coarse. Capt. C. B. J. Riccard’s g.b.h. Grey Dawn, 11.1. Lynch. _ 1 Capt. A. Loveband’s br.b.h. Soliman, 11.0. Owner. \ . 2 Capt. C. B. J. Riccard’s g.b.g. Hermit, 11.11. Owner. 3 Mr. S. G. Smithwiok’a bl.b.b. Blaok Arrow, 11.7. Mr. Stirling. 0
Mr. W. P. Stirling g.a.h. Two Step, 11.8. Gorman. 0 Capt. R. G. B. Jeffrey’s g.b.h. Balquholly, 11.9. Owner. j 0 Mr. A. W. Mdony’s bl.b.b. Kiloul’en, 12.7. Owner. 0 Mr. B.V. Knox’s g.b.h. Baloarie, ll.ll.Owner.O Shrimp, 11.0. Doffy. 0 Lt. Col. A. J. Chapman’s g.b.h. Ravaohol,11.7. Owner. 0 Capt. E. A. Molesworth’s g.ah. Quicksilver, 117. Hol’oway. • 0 Major G. Downing’s g.b.g. St. Michael, 11.7. Capt. Anderson. 0 Major G. Downing’s oh.a.h. St. Patriok, 12.0. Oliver. 0

All the horses jumped off together and kept so until nearing the J mile post, when toe field began to single out Soliman, Grey Dawn, and Hermit drew away from the rest and ran a free race home, Grey Dawn finally winning by a short head, three lengths separating second and third; The others were nowhere. Time : 9.44.
Totalisator paid P.T. 750 on winner and P.T. 105, 37, and 152 for places.

Pony Stakes of P.T. 9,500. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 500 out of the stakes. For Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance 6 furlongs Entrance P.T. 125. Hussein Pacha Sionfi’i g.a.p, Abon Nadara, 9.9. Mr. Paravioini.

Baron J. E. de Menasoe’s oh.a.p. Radium, 9.7. Matthews. 2 Ieh Bey Hussein’s ba.p. Shahronr, 9.7. Stillwell. 3 Khalil Paoha Khayat’s oh.a.p. Donghan, 9.3. Burnham. { 0 Mr. B. Karam’s b.a.p. Chafer, 9.7. Elia. 0 Capt. C. Cradock’s ch.a.p. Vino Tinto, 10.0. Lovebandl 0 Mr. A. J. Miohaelides’ g.a.p. Djsrry Boy. 9.3. Lambro. 0

Abou Nadara was the first to show in front coming out of the straight with Radium and Vino Tinto in close attendance. This order was maintained until half-way down the straight, when Vino Tinto was done with and 8hakrour took third place, Chater at his heels. Abon Nadara’s superiority was never once challenged and he won a close race by a length.
Totalisator paid P.T. 68 on winner and P.T. 28, 30, and 22 for places,

Ladies Bracelet of P.T. 2,000, presented by the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company, viz: P.T. 1,000 to the nominator of the winner and P.T. 1,000 to the owner together with P.T. 600 added to go to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never won a raoce except Gymkhanas. To be nominated by ladies. Horses 11.7. Ponies 10.11. Distance 6 furlongs.

Saleh Bey Yaghen’s g.a.h. Mabsout, 11.7. W hiteside. 1 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s g.a.h. Tokat, 11.7. Eliseo. 2 Mr. E. Karam’s g.a.h. Donglas, 11.7. Michae- lidee Jan. , 3 Ishaok Bay Hussein’s g.s.h. Kiamit, 11.7. Mr. MoColloDgb. 0 Ishaok Bey Hussein’s b.a.p. NusTut, 10.12. Stillwell. 0 Baron J. E. de Msnasce’s g.a.p.Heroule, 10.11. Matthews. 0 Mr. E. Karam’s g.a.h. Voltigenr, 11.8. Ibr. Hassan. 0 Hussein Pasha Sioufi’s b.a.p. Atragak, 10.11. Mr. Paravioini. 0 Prinoe Omar Pasha Toussoun’s g.a.p. Mleyhan, Ibrahim Bastawissi. 0 Ibrahim Boy Cherit’s g.a.h. Kordofan, 11.7. Parsons. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherit’s b.a.p. Sudan, 1011. Edward. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherit’s g.a.p. Atbara, 10.11. Kamel Effendi. 0 Mr. A.J. Sursock’a br.a.h. Nigri,10.7.Hassan. 0 Mr. A J. Sursock’s g.a.p. Karro, 10.11. Capt Loveband. 0 Hassan Bay Kheir el Din’s oh.a.p. Lonhan, 10.11. Megahed. 0 Khalil Paoha Khayat’s b.a.h. Kassban II., 11.7. Thompson. 0 Khalil Paoha Khayat’s b.a.h. Zariff III., 11.7. Burnham. 0

Some delay took place at the post owing to the big field, who were finally dispatched to a good start, but came into the straight in a procession, Mabsout leading the way, with Tokar and Nusrnt in attendance. Mabsout was never overtaken and came in an easy winner by 3 lengths, with two lengths separating second and third. Nusrnt lost a place half-way np the field, when Douglas passed him and Atbara. Time : 1.23.
Totalisator paid P.T. 68 on winner and P.T. 28,30, and 23 for places.

April Plate of P.T. 2,600. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 600 out of the stakes. For Arabs. Weight tor age with penalties. Distance round the course. Mr. A.J. Sursock’s br.a.h. Roi de l’Air, 10.7. Mr. Paravioini.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
"THE CRUCIFIXION."
div.p: It was with pleasure both reverent and sincere that we listened to the performance of Dr. Stainer’s sacred cantata "Crucifixion” in All Saints’ Church, Cairo, on Maundy Thursday. The work is an ambitious one, and is associated with cathedral choirs of known ability and training. That a result so good should be arrived at shows great patience and real love of the work, and Mr. Peacock deserves all commendation and praise. Thanks also are due to Mr.Gottlieb for his valuable help at the organ daring rehearsals. The tenor solos were sung by Mr. Roussain, whose sweet and cultivated voice filled the church with thrilling sympathy. The choir might have attacked the chorus "Fling wide the Gates” with greater force and more light and shade, but the following choruses were well presented. In ' The Appeal of the Crucifiad” the effect was dramatic and intense, and the choir at its beat as it reached the climax shooting with startling accuracy "Crucify, Crucify.” The bass solos were chiefly sustained by Captain Tucker. Unfortunately, he appeared to be suffering from cold, though there was no sign of it in the duet "Oh 'twas love" (Mrs. Roussin and Captain Tucker), which was beautifully rendered. We remember hearing this work in All Sainta’ some year or two ago. It is invidious making comparisons but we may add that Mr. Peacock is to be warmly congratulated on the efficiency of his choir.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Abbas Pacha Halim left for Constantinople by the Russian steamer on Friday.

The Hon. William J. Bryan, who twice stood as Democratic candidate for the Presidency of the United States of America, is now staying at Shepheard’s. Mr. Bryan is making a tour round the world in the course of which he has already visited the Hawaian Islands and Japan, where he had a remarkable reception, Korea, China, the Philippines, and India. Mr. Bryan left Cairo for Luxor on Monday night and will return on Thursday, leaving Cairo again on Saturday for a visit to the Holy Land. Mr. Bryan, whet is editor and proprietor of a weekly paper, “The Commoner,” which has one of the largest circulations in U.S.A., is writing S series of articles giving his impressions of his journey.

Sir Edward Clarke, KC-M.G., and Lady Clarke and their youngest son, Mr. William Clarke, left Shepheard’s Hotel yesterday for Port Said on their way back to England. Sir Edward intends to break his journey in Paris. He has greatly benefited by his visit and looks forward with much pleasure to renewing his work at the Bar and in Parliament.

Apropos of the visit of Sir Edward Clarke to Egypt and the simultaneous attack made upon him by the Protectionists in the City of London because of his attitude respecting tariff reform, the "Westminster Gazette” prints a clever and very amusing cartoon from the pencil of Mr. F. Carruthers Gould. Sir Edward, in full tourist costume, is pictured as seated on the back of a meek-looking donkey, from which position he surveys the 8phinx, the latter bearing the features of Mr. Arthur Balfour, with the addition of the famous monocle of the member for West Birmingham. Sir Edward is represented as making the following comment: "Dear me, so that’s the Sphinx. It’s uncommonly like both of them. I suppose it must be the effect of the mirage.”

Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., is still staying at Shepheard’s Hotel and has very much improved in health daring his long stay in Egypt. He is not leaving until next month and hopes to come out here again before Christmas.

General J. F. Owen, C.B., was placed on retired pay last week, on reaching the age limit. General Owen served in the Egyptian campaign of 1882, and was present at Tel-el- Kebir. He has been Chief of the Staff since 1904.

A very enjoyable garden party was given by Milhem Shakoor Bey and Mrs. 8hakoor at their charming house on Rodah Island yesterday. Among those present were Sir Horace and Lady Pinching, Dean and Mrs. Batcher, Mr. and Mrs. von Mohl, Shakoor Pasha, Mrs. Coles and the Misses Coles, Major and Mrs. Herbert, Col. Aylmer, Mr. Brunyate, Judge Took, Mr. and Mrs. Archer, Mr. and Mrs. Keatinge, Dr. and Mrs. Nolan, Mrs. Royle, Mr. Lewis, Mrs. and Miss Rees, Mrs. Bird- wood, Mrs. Sheldon Amos and Mr. Amos, Mr. and Mrs. Thomson, and very many others. The Reformatory band played selections in the garden, and the perfect weather aided to make the afternoon a most pleasant one.
Mr. McClure, of the Egyptian Constructions, Limited, is proceeding with his family to England in a fortnight’s time, and intends returning to Egypt in two or three months.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Algerian (Ellerman) sailed from Malta last Saturday and is doe here with a general cargo on Thursday morning.
The S.S. Sardinia (Ellerman) sailed from Liverpool on Saturday last with passengers and a general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.
The 8. S. Tuscan Prince, from Man oh ester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Saturday and is due at Alexandria on Wednesday.
The S. S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Friday and is due at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malta, on May 5.
The Canard S. S. Pavia is due here on 26th inst. and will immediately begin loading cargo for Liverpool and American ports.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
